Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Mechanics of a New Family of Auxetic Chiral Composites

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration: This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project will investigate the mechanical behavior of a new family of auxetic chiral composites which have unique deformation mechanisms and can preserve auxetic effects under large deformations. Based on an analytical mechanical model, a new family of auxetic chiral composites will be invented and their deformation mechanisms will be explored by finite element simulations, micro-polar theory, and mechanical experiments on multi-material 3D-printed specimens. Simultaneously, due to significant local rotation, these new micro-architectured materials provide excellent examples on the application of micro-polar theory and will be used to advance this important theory in mechanics. The rapid development of additive manufacturing (3D printing) enables easy and precise control of the geometry and material composition of micro-architectured hybrid materials, providing unprecedented opportunities to push the boundary of mechanics. This proposed research reveals a paradigm for using 3D printing as a tool to advance existing theories in mechanics and verify new engineering concepts.<br/><br/>The creation of new knowledge on the mechanics of this new family of auxetic chiral composites is expected to have potential broad applications in designing lightweight materials for mechanical protection and energy absorption, biomedical materials and devices to improve public health, and metamaterials and mechano-adaptive composites. The outreach and engagement activities are designed to be integrated with the educational activities and will be largely focused on the engagement and retention of underrepresented groups by threading seemingly traditional mechanical engineering concepts with innovation interdisciplinary concepts. This will be accomplished by (1) engaging participants across all different levels, from graduate and undergraduate students, elementary and middle school students and teachers to practicing engineers, (2) strengthening curriculum within and across the disciplines of mechanics, biomimetics, and additive manufacturing, (3) collaborating with local, small/middle scale, and high-added value industries to facilitate knowledge dissemination and technology transfer, and (4) developing K-12 outreach activities to support the newly released Next Generation Science Standards.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objective of this research project is to investigate the mechanical behavior of auxetic chiral cellular composites using an integrated method of analytical modeling, micropolar elasticity, finite element simulations, 3D printing, and mechanical experiments. Specifically, this research focused on (1) inventing a new family of auxetic chiral composites which can preserve auxetic effect under large deformation; (2) exploring the auxetic effects and new deformation mechanisms of this family of chiral structures; (3) using micropolar theory to quantify their mechanical behavior, and on the other hand, using these new materials to advance micropolar theory; (4) fabricating the novel designs through multi-material 3D printing; and (5) performing finite element simulations and mechanical experiments to verify the methodology developed. The major research outcome is briefly summarized as the following:

(1)   A new family of material were designed to have new deformation mechanisms and can preserve auxetic effect under large deformation.

(2)   The new deformation mechanisms include internal rotation, sequential cell opening mechanism, and couple compression-twisting

(3)   Micropolar modeling approach is used to predict the effective material properties at continuum level. For example, micropolar model was developed to predict the tunable Poisson?s ratio and effective stiffness of the material, Micropolar model was also developed to predict the anisotropy of the material

(4)   The effects of handedness distribution on the effective mechanical properties of the new material were also explored and it was found that by tuning the handedness distribution, the mechanical performance of the material can be further improved.

(5) Bi-axial compression and picture-frame shear apparatus were designed.

(6)   Prototypes of the new material were fabricated via multi-material 3D printing. Systematic mechanical experiments were performed. This proposed research reveals a paradigm for using 3D printing as a tool to advance existing theories in mechanics and prove and verify new engineering concepts.

This new family of chiral mechanical metamaterial have broad applications in designing lightweight materials for mechanical protection and energy absorption, biomedical materials and devices to improve public health, and metamaterials and mechano-adaptive composites which provide multi-mission capability for air, space and land assets.

Under the support of this award, one student has obtained his Ph.D. degree. One Ph.D. students was partially supported by this grant. One student has obtained the Master degree. One post-doc and six undergraduate students were involved in the research. So far, twelve journal/conference papers have been published, and one journal paper is under review. Three provisional patents were filed. Two non-provisional patents were filed. We have presented the results in numerous conferences including APS, SES, ASME/IMECE, and some local workshops and seminars as invited speakers. The project engaged participants including, graduate and undergraduate students, middle/elementary school teachers and students. The research outcome is also included to a new course that the PI designed. The new knowledge generated from this project is now taught in the classroom.

Specifically, this research focused on (1) inventing a new family of auxetic chiral composites which can preserve auxetic effect under large deformation; (2) exploring the auxetic effects and new deformation mechanisms of this family of chiral structures; (3) using micropolar theory to quantify their mechanical behavior, and on the other hand, using these new materials to advance micropolar theory; (4) fabricating the novel designs through multi-material 3D printing; and (5) performing finite element simulations and mechanical experiments to verify the methodology developed. The major research outcome is briefly summarized as the following: (1) A new family of material were designed to have new deformation mechanisms and can preserve auxetic effect under large deformation. (2) The new deformation mechanisms include internal rotation, sequential cell opening mechanism, and couple compression-twisting (3) Micropolar modeling approach is used to predict the effective material properties at continuum level. For example, micropolar model was developed to predict the tunable Poisson?s ratio and effective stiffness of the material, Micropolar model was also developed to predict the anisotropy of the material (4) The effects of handedness distribution on the effective mechanical properties of the new material were also explored and it was found that by tuning the handedness distribution, the mechanical performance of the material can be further improved. (5) Bi-axial compression and picture-frame shear apparatus were designed. (6) Prototypes of the new material were fabricated via multi-material 3D printing. Systematic mechanical experiments were performed. This proposed research reveals a paradigm for using 3D printing as a tool to advance existing theories in mechanics and prove and verify new engineering concepts.
